results.definition: a score in baseball made by a runner touching all four bases safely
examples: the Yankees scored 3 runs in the bottom of the 9th
their first tally came in the 3rd inning

results.definition: the act of testing something
examples: in the experimental trials the amount of carbon was measured separately
he called each flip of the coin a new trial

results.definition: a race run on foot
examples: she broke the record for the half-mile run

results.definition: an unbroken series of events
examples: had a streak of bad luck
Nicklaus had a run of birdies

results.definition: (American football) a play in which a player attempts to carry the ball through or past the opposing team
examples: the defensive line braced to stop the run
the coach put great emphasis on running

results.definition: a regular trip
examples: the ship made its run in record time

results.definition: the act of running; traveling on foot at a fast pace
examples: he broke into a run
his daily run keeps him fit

results.definition: the continuous period of time during which something (a machine or a factory) operates or continues in operation
examples: the assembly line was on a 12-hour run

results.definition: unrestricted freedom to use
examples: he has the run of the house

results.definition: the production achieved during a continuous period of operation (of a machine or factory etc.)
examples: a daily run of 100,000 gallons of paint

results.definition: a small stream
a race between candidates for elective office
examples: I managed his campaign for governor
he is raising money for a Senate run

results.definition: a row of unravelled stitches
examples: she got a run in her stocking

results.definition: the pouring forth of a fluid
an unbroken chronological sequence
examples: the play had a long run on Broadway
the team enjoyed a brief run of victories

results.definition: a short trip
examples: take a run into town

results.definition: move fast by using one's feet, with one foot off the ground at any given time
examples: Don't run--you'll be out of breath
The children ran to the store

results.definition: flee; take to one's heels; cut and run
examples: If you see this man, run!
The burglars escaped before the police showed up

results.definition: stretch out over a distance, space, time, or scope; run or extend between two points or beyond a certain point
examples: Service runs all the way to Cranbury
His knowledge doesn't go very far
My memory extends back to my fourth year of life
The facts extend beyond a consideration of her personal assets

results.definition: direct or control; projects, businesses, etc.
examples: She is running a relief operation in the Sudan

results.definition: have a particular form
examples: the story or argument runs as follows
as the saying goes...

results.definition: move along, of liquids
examples: Water flowed into the cave
the Missouri feeds into the Mississippi

results.definition: perform as expected when applied
examples: The washing machine won't go unless it's plugged in
Does this old car still run well?
This old radio doesn't work anymore

results.definition: change or be different within limits
examples: Estimates for the losses in the earthquake range as high as $2 billion
Interest rates run from 5 to 10 percent
The instruments ranged from tuba to cymbals
My students range from very bright to dull

results.definition: run, stand, or compete for an office or a position
examples: Who's running for treasurer this year?

results.definition: cause to emit recorded audio or video
examples: They ran the tapes over and over again
I'll play you my favorite record
He never tires of playing that video

results.definition: move about freely and without restraint, or act as if running around in an uncontrolled way
examples: who are these people running around in the building?
She runs around telling everyone of her troubles
let the dogs run free

results.definition: have a tendency or disposition to do or be something; be inclined
examples: She tends to be nervous before her lectures
These dresses run small
He inclined to corpulence

results.definition: be operating, running or functioning
examples: The car is still running--turn it off!

results.definition: change from one state to another
examples: run amok
run rogue
run riot

results.definition: cause to perform
examples: run a subject
run a process

results.definition: be affected by; be subjected to
examples: run a temperature
run a risk

results.definition: continue to exist
examples: These stories die hard
The legend of Elvis endures

results.definition: occur persistently
examples: Musical talent runs in the family

results.definition: carry out a process or program, as on a computer or a machine
examples: Run the dishwasher
run a new program on the Mac
the computer executed the instruction

results.definition: include as the content; broadcast or publicize
examples: We ran the ad three times
This paper carries a restaurant review
All major networks carried the press conference

results.definition: carry out
examples: run an errand

results.definition: pass over, across, or through
examples: He ran his eyes over her body
She ran her fingers along the carved figurine
He drew her hair through his fingers

results.definition: cause something to pass or lead somewhere
examples: Run the wire behind the cabinet

results.definition: make without a miss
deal in illegally, such as arms or liquor
cause an animal to move fast
examples: run the dogs

results.definition: be diffused
examples: These dyes and colors are guaranteed not to run

results.definition: sail before the wind
cover by running; run a certain distance
examples: She ran 10 miles that day

results.definition: extend or continue for a certain period of time
examples: The film runs 5 hours

results.definition: set animals loose to graze
keep company
examples: the heifers run with the bulls to produce offspring

results.definition: run with the ball; in such sports as football
travel rapidly, by any (unspecified) means
examples: Run to the store!
She always runs to Italy, because she has a lover there

results.definition: travel a route regularly
examples: Ships ply the waters near the coast

results.definition: pursue for food or sport (as of wild animals)
examples: Goering often hunted wild boars in Poland
The dogs are running deer
The Duke hunted in these woods

results.definition: compete in a race
examples: he is running the Marathon this year
let's race and see who gets there first

results.definition: progress by being changed
examples: The speech has to go through several more drafts
run through your presentation before the meeting

results.definition: reduce or cause to be reduced from a solid to a liquid state, usually by heating
examples: melt butter
melt down gold
The wax melted in the sun

results.definition: come unraveled or undone as if by snagging
examples: Her nylons were running

results.definition: become undone
examples: the sweater unraveled
